description: Ayrshire was one of the first health boards to receive a positive COVID-19 test. Ayrshire has the third-worst COVID-19 death rate in Scotland. Grampian, which has more than 200,000 more residents than Ayrshire has one of the lowest death rates in Scotland.
text:
Ayrshire was one of the first health boards to receive a positive COVID-19
test.

March 4 \- the date of the first case in the region - seems like a distant
memory now with cases now sitting at 1080 today.

What has the virus done at a local level and how does the region compare with
the rest of Scotland's health boards?

Deaths per 10,000 of population

Ayrshire has the third-worst COVID-19 death rate in Scotland.

The region has seen 7.5 per 10,000 deaths with only Greater Glasgow and Clyde
(10.7) and Lanarkshire (8.1) recording higher numbers.

Lothian, with a population size almost three times that of Ayrshire, has
recorded 7.4 deaths per 10,000.

Tayside, with a slightly larger population than Ayrshire reported a figure of
6.9. Grampian, which has more than 200,000 more residents than Ayrshire has
one of the lowest death rates (4.1) in Scotland.

Deaths by Ayrshire Council area

South Ayrshire has recorded the largest number of coronavirus-related deaths
in Ayrshire.

Up to May 31, 105 people have died in the area with 101 deaths in North
Ayrshire and 70 in East.

Coronavirus deaths by setting

A total of 44 per cent of COVID-19 deaths in Ayrshire took place in care
homes.

This is slightly below the national picture, which is currently at 46 per
cent.

Hospital deaths in Ayrshire accounted for the majority of coronavirus deaths
(49 per cent).

Meanwhile, home or non-institutional deaths accounted for seven per cent of
the region's virus deaths.

Breaking this down further into local authorities, more South Ayrshire
residents have died in hospital (49 per cent) compared to care homes (47 per
cent).

The majority of North Ayrshire deaths took place in hospital (47 per cent)
while 44 per cent took place in care homes.

In East Ayrshire, hospital deaths accounted for 51 per cent of COVID-19
fatalities, while 41 per cent of deaths occurred in care homes.

Coronavirus cases

Cases are still increasing across Ayrshire but the amount of cases being
confirmed has been reduced dramatically.

We're only a handful of days into June but May saw Ayrshire record almost half
the number of COVID-19 reported in April.

April saw 585 confirmed cases reported, while May saw a total of 298 cases.

Hospital numbers

There has been a huge shift in the number of hospital patients with
coronavirus too since the Scottish Government started releasing the
information on Wednesday, April 8.

The number of patients with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 was at its highest
on Monday, April 20 when 129 people were in hospital.

Recently, hospital numbers were at the lowest they've ever been (8)  a 93 per
cent reduction since the peak.

title: In numbers: How coronavirus is taking its toll on Ayrshire
html:
Ayrshire was one of the first health boards to receive a positive COVID-19 test.

March 4 - the date of the first case in the region - seems like a distant memory now with cases now sitting at 1080 today.

What has the virus done at a local level and how does the region compare with the rest of Scotland's health boards?

Deaths per 10,000 of population

Ayrshire has the third-worst COVID-19 death rate in Scotland.

The region has seen 7.5 per 10,000 deaths with only Greater Glasgow and Clyde (10.7) and Lanarkshire (8.1) recording higher numbers.

Lothian, with a population size almost three times that of Ayrshire, has recorded 7.4 deaths per 10,000.

Tayside, with a slightly larger population than Ayrshire reported a figure of 6.9. Grampian, which has more than 200,000 more residents than Ayrshire has one of the lowest death rates (4.1) in Scotland.

Deaths by Ayrshire Council area

South Ayrshire has recorded the largest number of coronavirus-related deaths in Ayrshire.

Up to May 31, 105 people have died in the area with 101 deaths in North Ayrshire and 70 in East.

Coronavirus deaths by setting

A total of 44 per cent of COVID-19 deaths in Ayrshire took place in care homes.

This is slightly below the national picture, which is currently at 46 per cent.

Hospital deaths in Ayrshire accounted for the majority of coronavirus deaths (49 per cent).

Meanwhile, home or non-institutional deaths accounted for seven per cent of the region's virus deaths.

Breaking this down further into local authorities, more South Ayrshire residents have died in hospital (49 per cent) compared to care homes (47 per cent).

The majority of North Ayrshire deaths took place in hospital (47 per cent) while 44 per cent took place in care homes.

In East Ayrshire, hospital deaths accounted for 51 per cent of COVID-19 fatalities, while 41 per cent of deaths occurred in care homes.

Coronavirus cases

Cases are still increasing across Ayrshire but the amount of cases being confirmed has been reduced dramatically.

We're only a handful of days into June but May saw Ayrshire record almost half the number of COVID-19 reported in April.

April saw 585 confirmed cases reported, while May saw a total of 298 cases.

Hospital numbers

There has been a huge shift in the number of hospital patients with coronavirus too since the Scottish Government started releasing the information on Wednesday, April 8.

The number of patients with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 was at its highest on Monday, April 20 when 129 people were in hospital.

Recently, hospital numbers were at the lowest they've ever been (8) – a 93 per cent reduction since the peak.
